commentBody: The plural of “lei” is “lei.”

A collection of scientists using microscopes is a focus group.

(Just let this one slide.)

One little quibble:  Shouldn't the answer to the "Ph. D" clue consist of two words, the first of which starts with PH and the second with D?

!!!!

!!!!

Paging Captain Q.

We need you at 6 Across.





Nice one, Matthew and Brooke!
It has SPARK and STYLE.

Got hung up for a while on POCKET HARD DRIVE, which is a term that I doubt anybody has used in the last twenty years and was never common parlance in any case. Otherwise the other themers were pretty fun.

First in a long time I have seen braille alphabet as a crossword clue answer. Grew up with a blind family member so I truly appreciated this. Got pocket immediately and had to get hard drive with a few downs and then fill in the blanks. Enjoyed this overall
That was a fun puzzle but 3D is incorrect. Canada is NATO's largest member in geographic terms, which is the way I think most people would read the clue.

How come sometimes the little “i” shows the puzzle title and other times it doesn’t? Didn’t matter for my solve today but it annoys me when the wordplay column references the title as if it’s something we should know. (Or is there just no title today / is it somewhere else? NYT puzzle app user here)

POCKET HARD DRIVE being like a flash drive? Or a floppy? Or a portable/external hard drive? 

Anyone calling something a pocket hard drive may be a DODO in the obsolete meaning of the word. Which also doesn't usually mean obsolete without "going the way of"

PhD in interaction design?

PUSHHEREDUMMY

This might be the first time ever, in four years of solving crosswords, that I breezed through a puzzle by Matthew Stock and Brooke Husic.

I'm stoked!

It didn't start out that way, of course, as I skimmed the clues and only got a toe-hold in the lower center, with RIO and DODO. 
And I just realized that it does indeed say something about me! – I do, after all, have a foot in (another) Rio, and I can attest to being  a dodo sometimes (case in point, how I had almost finished the puzzle before I caught on to the gimmick.)

I truly had a blast with this solve and how it seamlessly opened up.

Thank you, Matthew and Brooke!
You both are truly ICONIC.
Birth day party was delightful.

Done in by a one(a) two (d) punch. 
Great puzzle, very clean, very fun, just a bit of an evil way to start, something I’m sure was intended.
Not that it mattered as thole was new to me, but it seems like it should be in between tholes.
Always amazed that DOULA is acceptable language.

Coincidentally, and aptly, my final entry was 29D If you can't get enough of Brooke's puzzles, they constructed yesterday's in The New Yorker too: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2024/10/22 (The New Yorker one took me almost 5 minutes longer than this one, so perhaps a bit more challenging.)
Ahhhhh, PLOYS not PLOtS -- that had me hunting at the end, but since I've never eaten RtE bread, I figured it out....
Needed even more help than usual to solve this tough but impressive Wednesday puzzle .

I was expecting to see lots of comments referring to this as more of a Tuesday puzzle. Breezed through this one, must have been on same wavelength today. Record Wednesday time and less than half my average time!

Tough one for me, and must confess that I had to stop and ponder for a bit even after I filled everything in to entirely grasp the theme. No complaint - that's all on me. Puzzle find today - with my compulsive letter counting, it dawned on me this morning that: ITSRAININGCATSANDDOGS is 21 letters. And... it was an answer once. It was the 'reveal' in a Sunday puzzle from January 5, 2012 by Finn Vigeland with the title: "Weather report." The other theme answers were all downs, with scattered letters in them highlighted. A couple of examples (capitalizing the highlighted letters): CAblesItCOms - (CALICO) BrEAkinGtheruLEs - (BEAGLE) MAsoNdiXonline - (MANX) antiPERSpIrANt - (PERSIAN) Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/15/2012&g=66&d=A I'm done. ..

In my print version the tractor tag line sat right at top center so I jumped in there and solved bottom up, including the reveal.  Big mistake.  

Just like the DEGREEs my level of achievement diminished as I moved up and I did not catch on until I reached the first tier.   Oh well, still good fun.   

Many thanks.  Going to put on that Dylan song . . .

. . . LEI LEIA LEIS.
Loved Wordle today!  Very clever.

Fun and breezy! 

Liked seeing  DEV and PATEL snuck in the NE.

Happy hump day!

If I only had the CLAMs to take hubby out
for a nice mid-week dinner.

Meatloaf and mashed it is!
Great puzzle and according to the post solve note, my 100th consecutive Wednesday.

Maybe it's me but I've never heard "pocket hard drive" used (@barry a no need to post a google search -- I'm sure it was used somewhere for a brief time). But I think it would be better clued as "PhD in Human Sexuality"!  :)

Did anyone catch the concurrence of DEV and PATEL?

Re: DOULA--if this word is questionable because of its etymology, it's not the fault of the constructor, who is merely applying a brilliant clue to what is now a common and tacitly accepted word. Rather, it is the fault of the culture that adopted it.
This was a relatively hard Wednesday for me — it took 35% longer than average to solve.  The theme answers came a lot more slowly than usual.  Nice challenge.
Great theme and a fast Wednesday for me.  Any day after Tuesday with no look-ups is a bonus.

I once thought that the growing use of DOULA in crosswords was evidence of recognition of our profession. As a solver, though, I realize it’s got more to do with vowels, and handy consonants. Nonetheless, I’ll take the win. We’re in good company, along with Alan ALDA and Felipe ALOU -- two of my favourite crossword personalities.

General post(s) theme: The puzzle was hard and fun. 

We agree and got a gold star for it.

GAGA over the puzzle Matt and Brooke, thank you.

This one was a really good example of what I think I’ve said before—the puzzles seem to be getting easier…until they aren’t. I breezed through, loved the theme, and then got stuck in the sw corner on what was a little natick cluster for me. It seemed a very quick Wednesday til then.

Nice Wednesday puzzle. The theme was clever and funny. I had my suspicions about 1A, and sure enough, there was no cake or ice cream involved. The "space buns" clue brought a smile. Only one lookup. 

This was a terrific contrast to Wednesday puzzles that are too difficult to be fun. Some tricky clues, but most of the answers only required general knowledge.

Let's have more verbal music from Husic!
I was on my high school MATHTEAM. We went to State! What a bunch a nerds.
I completed the puzzle but had absolutely no idea what the theme meant until I read the wordplay article.

John DEERE dealerships are thick on the ground in these parts.  My recent visit from brother Ric and his lady-friend had an entertaining moment (as they were exclaiming in shock that MS does not have a Trader Joe anywhere in the state) was the revelation that the population of Mississippi is 3 million.  (Their neighborhood in NoVA is larger than that.  Okay, I lied.  It's 2.9 million.  

Having started down in the SW, I solved bottom up and had a few "What?" moments.  Is there really such a thing as a POCKET HARD DRIVE?  And how is "gets along well" translated into GELS, which I would have clued as "comes together" or "forms into".....?  I guess I see it...dimly....

Well, on with the day!  Likely to be late to the party tomorrow, as I have fasting LABS to start my day--woo hoo--followed by Annual Wellness, followed by a DexaScan, and somewhere in there a HAIRCUT.  I hope I can stand the excitement.  All y'all behave.
Amused by 49A-- in my first fill I typed in GAY but figured it wouldn't be that explicit. One of the best books I've read, well deserving of a 5-star Goodreads review and homage in this puzzle.
Clever one. It took me a while to let go of DEBUT for birth day party!

Was the choice of BUY or paY a trap carefully laid at 10A?  I fell right into it and had a hard time getting 10D or 11D immediately thereafter.  My "pearls" looked for all the world like pOBA -- and I had no idea what that was.

Also, when I obtain something from logic, I DEDUCE (30D).  That blasted 2nd D made it look like the answer to the Tinder clue was going to be FIDO.  Which was perfectly silly.  But eventually I straightened everything out.

I enjoyed the resistance of a harder-than-usual Wednesday puzzle and I thought the revealer worked.  But I do have the sneaking suspicion that the idea for the puzzle occurred to the constructors first -- and that they then set about finding a revealer for it.  (I have no idea whatsoever why I think that.)  Anyway, a very nice Wednesday.

TIL DOULA.  and btw, PLOtS are also cunning plans even though RtE isn't an alternative to white or wheat. But my brain wouldn't get to RYE. 





Old brain......I hope the EMUs aren't hungry.

Well, I knew I was no longer trendy,  but 62A proved it. Wish that could have been the column picture. 
  Puzzle went very smoothly. Feeling chuffed at having plunked in the last 6 letters of the revealer straight off. But not so chuffed at how long it took to come up with the rest of it.
Yesterday's fun and interesting subsitute teacher was replaced with yet another today...actually two!...an inspirig pedagogic team!  Bravo et brava!! Look forwrd to your return!

I got hung up for a little while with NOTHING STOPS A DEERE. I was so sure it was the slogan for Trane, which manufactures HVAC products. But after getting the correct answer from the crosses I went to the Trane website, where it gives their slogan as It's Hard to Stop a Trane. Close, but no cigar. At least I figured it out.

Looking at the top comments it seems I am the only one underwhelmed by the theme today. It would’ve been more fun if the abbreviations were legitimate, rather than made up. 

I rate this theme 1/10..

Am I the only sailor here?  To moor a boat has nothing to do with a dock.  It's putting the boat on a mooring--one of those buoys you see out in the harbor. Putting it on a dock is docking your boat (and if you're a viking, you'd better dock it on the Port side, so you don't mess up your Starboard).  This is the second time I've seen it misused in the NYT crossword.  

Enjoy doing this every day!  It's a victory if I don't need a cheat or two on the wednesday puzzle.
OK Wednesday offering but I don't get how AmEx (which I know as an alternative to NYSE) is a "plastic option." What am I missing?

I call BS on this puzzle!

But seriously....GAYLIT was a surprise to me, as I had assumed that James Baldwin wrote exclusively on matters of race. Maybe if I'd ever bothered to read any of his work?

The theme was somewhat underwhelming, IMHO. The BRAILLEALPHABET is at least a specific (and interesting) thing, unlike a MICROSCOPESLIDE or a POCKETHARDDRIVE (which I've never heard of, despite being a bit of computing geek).

Frankly, today's Connections was more interesting. Let me it there.

Bested some cruciverbalists.

(That is my introductory assessment, based on the available crossword science.)

Since we don’t have a connections forum, I loved today’s connection.  Had it once I saw “purple rain” and “yellow journalism.” I wasn’t expecting all of them to match up to the colors.  that was quite clever.

I liked this one a lot. It was witty! Didn’t take too long but very stuck in the Southwest and forgot James Baldwin was gay, but “as in” should have given me a clue to look that up! I try not to do lookups but in this case would’ve learned something. Grateful to Sam for AMEX!

I was a bit disappointed by the theme, the answers were rather random, I thought there might be something to tie things together more. It would’ve been cool if they all shared something or had to do with the word “matter” in A matter of degree.
The Hawaiian language does not use "s" for plural words.  Lei is used for one lei or two lei.
Canada is the largest NATO member, not USA

Generally enjoyed this puzzle, but despite being a person who reads a tonnnn of queer fiction, I'm not a fan of 49A. I feel like it's not really a term people use?? and it put two answers where you had to know trivia together and instead it could have just been GAsLIT and sALE and you still could have come up with fun clues for those and it wouldn't have been as esoteric.
Doula? I done learned a new word on a Wednesday!

@Susan Avallon In Hawaiian, maybe, but this is an English puzzle, and there's no indication that we need a word in another language. https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/lei https://www.dictionary.com/browse/lei https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/lei (The tamale trap rides again!)
@Susan Avallon MW, dictionary com, and Wiktionary all list LEIS as an acceptable plural form
@Susan Avallon can’t get anything past the Steves!

@Susan Avallon It's curious how the response to little corrections like this is never "thanks for pointing that out, I learned something today" but instead always a vigorous defense of the "legitimacy" of the clue/answer. Even though your original comment never even said anything about legitimacy one way or the other. I'm regularly surprised by the lack of intellectual curiosity in these comments. Learning how to be more correct isn't something to run away from. 

Anyway, thanks for the comment and the mini lesson.

@Shrike Yes, especially when the word is in an Indigenous language … insisting on the legitimacy of the English plural is repeating the same dynamic whereby the lei becomes an accessory for tourists rather than a tradition with a specific history and meaning in Hawai’i. A little more care would be well placed here.

Shrike and Emily,

As I trust you both know, 
unless otherwise indicated, 
puzzle answers are in English. 

I would hope a poster whose interest 
is sharing information, rather than 
saying or implying the puzzle is incorrect, 
would start such a post 
with "In Hawaiian, ..."

@Shrike 

SRSLY?

First of all, the fact that the comment was made means Susan was questioning the legitimacy of the clue. Otherwise, why make it?

Why didn't I say "thanks for pointing that out, I learned something today"? Because I didn't. I'm aware that Hawaiian has only 13 letters, one of which is the 'okina, and that the S isn't one of them.  

Now, let's learn something about crosswords.

Crosswords use words that are in the dictionary. The English dictionary, that is, unless there's a foreign language signal. LEIS is in the English dictionary. Several of them, in fact. And that is the end of the story.

Now, let's talk about English.  English has a rule that plurals are formed by adding -s or -es to a word.  This is the case in far more than 99% of the words that exist.  The only exceptions are words that were so common under Anglo-Norman rules (children, sheep) that they never converted to the new rules.  And they are extremely few.

When a word is borrowed into English, its plural **in English** is formed with -s or -es, regardless of its native plural. You go to Starbucks and ask for two lattes, not two latti. You may say that your friend's kids look like cherubs, not cherubim (although you might use the latter when talking about actual angels). And sometimes you use a word that's natively plural for singular:  No one says "Spaghetti are my favorite Italian dish."

So LEIS is correct in English.  Plural LEI may be "more correct" in Hawaiian, but not in English.

@Shrike I don't think a lack of intellectual curiosityis involved in the case of a plural form.  Because language changes over time, there are often different acceptable forms.  Do you use pled or pleaded?  Most people use both:  He pled guilty BUT he pleaded with me to stop.  Do you say Euro or Euros?  An Irish student of mine definitely had opinions on my adding the s!  I think commenters are just pointing out that variants are acceptable.  It's not just the perhaps overly non-prescriptive Merriam-Webster that shows leis as the plural of lei but also the practical and serviceable Oxford Learner's Dictionary.  Thus, correcting it seems either prejudiced or pedantic.

@Emily I wonder if Hawaiians have adopted any English words into their languages and if so, whether the grammar of their languages has influenced usage.  Certainly we see this here in Germany, where English nouns and verbs are routinely given non-English endings to adapt them for easy use when speaking German.  Languages borrow words from each other; they also evolve and change.  This is the nature of language and cannot be changed by fiats from purists and nor yet from virtue-signalers.
@Steve L Well said.

@Emily 

The implication that pluralizing a loanword according to the English rule smacks of colonialism is ridiculous. This phenomenon occurs regardless of what language a word is borrowed from.  (See latte above, and by the way, we even changed the original meaning [milk] on that one.)

@Steve L The difference is context—Italian isn’t currently the object of revitalization efforts; Hawaiian is, because it was almost wiped out after colonization and laws that forbid it to be taught in schools. The claiming and circulation of Hawaiian words and concepts (like aloha, hula, or lei) in ways divorced from their actual use and meaning is also part of that ongoing colonial history.
@Mike  That would be the ultimate zoom call. (This won't bear too close an examination.)

@Mike 

Take care when you focus not to bat an eye.

Mike,

Magnifico!

Hope you enjoyed!

Thanks for replying.  I did enjoy; I really do like you two's puzzles--separately and together--a lot.  But that one clue/answer just jumped out at me.  

I operate from the position that all NYT puzzles are at the very least very good, and some are better than others.  My nits are just that, not major issues.

@Shrike 

With the prevalence of thumb drives and SSDs, the size of hard drives has shrunk. From the days of platter-type drives that might fit in someone's back pocket, you now have multi-terabyte drives that can fit in a shirt pocket or any pants pocket. I haven't heard "pocket hard drive" used, but the term is consistent with the hardware size.
@JayTee I'm no geek but I remember this term.  Shows my age, I suppose.
@Shrike I currently have a "pocket" hard drive, providing backups for my laptop. Wouldn't fit in a pants pocket though - needs something more like an overcoat pocket...

@JayTee those however are not hard drives, which is a term specifically used for magnetic storage with moving parts. Thumb drives and the like are solid state storage, and are not referred to as hard drives.
@Ed it’s one way to read the clue, but that doesn’t make the alternatives (largest by population, largest by GDP, largest by spend) less correct.
@Ed Canada didn't fit. I got it straightaway.
@Ed crosswords often try to misdirect you to a more “popular”answer instead of the less obvious, but still acceptable, actual answer. USA is an acceptable answer because it’s largest by population.
@Jared that would be most populous. These are word games after all. Accuracy is important.  Canada is (a little) larger than the US but the US is (much) more populous than Canada.

@Jared I respectfully disagree - if there are degrees of correctness  then those interpretations are less correct. If your sister earns more money than you, pays more taxes than you, and has more kids than you, does that make her the larger member of your family?

@Ιασων I didn’t know the origin of the word. Here’s an interesting discussion about its continued use. https://healthlaw.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/Doula-Terminology-Issue-Brief-FINAL.pdf
@Ιασων Why? It’s not an uncommon word in my experience.
@Amanda never mind, google answered this for me! I had no idea.

@Justin 
Thanks for posting this Justin -- really interesting.  I work as a doula, in English and French. In French I am an "accompagnante à la naissance". At first I much preferred that term, but there is no great translation of it (I don't care for birth companion, or birth advocate). Over the years I've warmed to the word doula. Everyone uses it now, often in French as well, and it has more and more of a positive connotation (even among many -- but not all -- doctors and nurses in hospitals).

@Ιασων 

Judging by your handle, I assume you know Greek. By that standard, it's clear that you're an insider and know why DOULA ( not δούλα) might be problematic. This is indeed a case where I learned something I did not know before.  

But one might consider if that problem exists when δούλα leaves Greek and becomes DOULA in English. Words change their meaning and their etymology is forgotten in a new language. LATTE becomes a coffee drink with milk in it, and not just milk. German borrows our HANDY and SMOKING and they become their words for cellphone and tuxedo, respectively. Italian takes our FEELING and uses it to mean chemistry between people.

As far as the connection to slavery goes, the Slavic people had better change their ethnonym, since that and the word for forced servitude are etymologically related. And Italians and all those who borrow their greetings had better stop saying "Ciao", since it's also related to servitude. And God forbid we refer to a "master bedroom" anymore. I'd better give back my master's degree, too.

As to gender, words go from single gender to unisex and back all the time. MAN once referred to all humans, and still can (man's inhumanity to man). But we get caught up in gender politics and forget that words can have multiple meanings and conveniently lose sight of etymology when it's convenient to.

Bottom line: Replace DOULA if you can, but most people don't find any problem with it because etymology only counts so much.
@Steve L Well said, again.  We seem to have much in common in the realm of language usage.

@Steve L all good points. Yes I am Greek and one would never call someone a doula in Greek. If the appropriation of the word was old then it could be excused as language evolution. However, the introduction into English came in the 1960s. In full knowledge of the term. 

I’m only surprised that in the US where words are culturally weaponized  this term is acceptable.

Both my sailboat and my stinkboat have mooring lines. (Or hawsers, if you will.) @Xword Junkie 

Pocket hard drive is just bogus, unfortunately.  Portable hard drive, sure, but pocket hard drive is not a term that many people have ever used.  I well remember when smaller 2.5" portable hard drives became more prevalent.  These could arguably be called the first pocketable ones.

No one called them pocket hard drives.

And if the constructors were thinking of USB flash drives or something, well then I suppose they didn't know what a hard drive is?  Agreed - all the theme answers today could have been better.

@Mick I simply wrote that I’ve never heard of a POCKETHARDDRIVE. Like you, I did a search after finishing the puzzle, and saw that such a thing exists. To me, it remains an uninteresting item that was plucked from obscurity simply to complete a not particularly interesting theme. IMHO,

@Mick Some random dude putting it in an encyclopedia for his adult ed classes doesn't mean it was a term that was used by many people. Interesting that what is left of PC Magazine is hosting it though. Here's an NGram search corroborating my position that for practical purposes no one used the term, ever. https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=pocket+hard+drive%2C+portable+hard+drive&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&corpus=en&smoothing=3 And as to products, it should really go without saying that due to marketing efforts you can find hits by searching on basically ANYTHING....
